title: 110_s1276
content: The Methamphetamine Production Prevention Act of 2008 clarifies signature capture and retention for electronic methamphetamine precursor logbook systems under the Controlled Substances Act. The Methamphetamine Production Prevention Act of 2008 clarifies requirements for electronic methamphetamine precursor logbook systems under the Controlled Substances Act, including the need for purchasers to present valid identification and sign the logbook. The Methamphetamine Production Prevention Act of 2008 requires purchasers to sign a device or bound paper book to capture signatures in an electronic format, linking them to other logbook information. The Methamphetamine Production Prevention Act of 2008 mandates purchasers to sign a printed sticker or unique identifier in a bound paper book at the time of sale, linking it to electronic information. The book must also display a specific notice. The Methamphetamine Production Prevention Act of 2008 requires purchasers to sign a printed document at the time of sale, containing details of the products sold, quantity, purchaser's information, and sale date. The document must be printed by the seller, include a signature line, and display a specific notice. Each signed document should be stored securely after the sale. After signing the document, it should be securely stored in a binder or other means of document storage. The seller records product name and quantity sold in a logbook, which can be done electronically. The logbook also includes purchaser's name, address, date, and time of sale. The seller must verify purchaser information entered in the logbook, which can be done electronically. The logbook includes a notice about entering false statements. The seller must maintain logbook entries for at least 2 years and provide a notice to purchasers about the consequences of entering false information, including criminal penalties.
